repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Mount Vernon Seminary and College Media collection

physdesc.extent: 2 over-size video tape boxes, 1 flat box, 2 letter-size document boxes, 12 film cans

did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.
did.abstract: The Mount Vernon Seminary began in 1875 as a private high school and junior college for women, founded by Elizabeth J. Somers. The George Washington University initially affiliated with Mount Vernon College, and ultimately acquired the college's property and legacy in 1999. This collection contains videotapes, audio cassettes, audio tape reels, 8 mm film, 16 mm film, and a 35 mm film from the Mount Vernon Seminary and College archives. The recordings capture campus scenes, ceremonies, celebrations, and student life predominately on the Spring Valley and Foxhall Road campuses of Mount Vernon Seminary and College. They range in date from 1925 to 1999, with the bulk of the media dating between 1946 and 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains videotapes, audio cassettes, audio tape reels, 8 mm film, 16 mm film, and a 35 mm film from the Mount Vernon Seminary and College archives. The recordings capture campus scenes, ceremonies, celebrations, and student life predominately on the Spring Valley and Foxhall Road campuses of Mount Vernon Seminary and College. They range in date from 1925 to 1999, with the bulk of the media dating between 1946 and 1999.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Mount Vernon Seminary began in 1875 as a private high school and junior college for women, founded by Elizabeth J. Somers. The George Washington University initially affiliated with Mount Vernon College, and ultimately acquired the college's property and legacy in 1999.
The first school of higher education available to women in Washington, D.C., Mount Vernon Seminary and College had five different locations throughout its history:
1875-1880: Elizabeth Somers began tutoring the young daughters of prominent Washington men in her home at 204 F Street, NW in Washington, DC.
1880-1917: The school moved to 1100 M Street, NW where it expanded rapidly to include three additional houses, a courtyard, tennis court, and basketball court.

1917-1942: Having outgrown its M Street location, the school moved to a 15.5-acre campus on Nebraska Avenue, NW. The buildings and layout of the campus were designed by a New York architect, Wesley S. Bessell. and the campus was formally dedicated on November 5, 1917 -- Mrs. Somers' 80th birthday. In 1942, the United States Navy took over the Nebraska Avenue campus to use its facilities for the war effort.
1943-1946: The school resumed courses in February 1943 at the top floor of a Garfinckel's department store building in the Spring Valley neighborhood of Washington, D.C.

1946-1999: Between 1944 and 1946, the school built a new 21-acre campus located on Foxhall Road in Washington, D.C. using money granted to the college by the United States Navy in compensation for the military takeover of its property.

The last Seminary class graduated in 1969, and the school was then officially renamed to Mount Vernon Junior College. In 1976, Mount Vernon College became an accredited four year college. In 1997, the Board of Trustees decided that the College would close as an independent institution. As of June 30, 1999, Mount Vernon became affiliated with The George Washington University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: Films, Videos, Audio Cassettes, and Audio Tape Reels.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Mount Vernon Seminary and College archives were acquired by GWU upon merger with Mount Vernon College. The collection was transferred to the Foggy Bottom campus in 2009.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by film gauge, beginning with 16 mm films, then the 35 mm film, and finally the 8 mm films.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains silent 16 mm and 8 mm films, and one 35 mm film. The films depict campus scenes, ceremonies, celebrations, and student life predominately on the Spring Valley and Foxhall Road campuses of Mount Vernon Seminary and College. They range in date from 1925 to 1968, with the bulk of the films dating between 1946 and 1956. Of note are Films 13 and 19 capturing Mount Vernon Seminary's fiftieth anniversary Golden Jubilee celebrations; the centenary celebration of the birth of Mount Vernon Seminary founder, Elizabeth J. Somers, in Film 1; and Foxhall Road campus groundbreaking, construction, and dedication ceremonies in Films 9, 14, 15, 17, and 18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains VHS and betacam videotapes. The videos depict ceremonies, celebrations, and other special events on the Foxhall Road campus of Mount Vernon College. Subjects include the dedication ceremony for Eckles Library, the inauguration of President LucyAnn Geiselman, convocations, baccalaureates, commencements, Founder's Day celebrations, and Symposia on Women in Politics and Journalism. They range in date from 1987 to 1999.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, with undated videos at the end of the sequence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains audio tape cassettes. The tapes capture campus ceremonies, celebrations, and special events on the Foxhall Road campus of Mount Vernon Seminary and College, particularly commencement ceremonies. They range in date from 1961 to 1999, with the bulk of the tapes dating between 1972 and 1999.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically with undated tapes at the end of the sequence.

did.unittitle: "A School Which Hath Foundations" Founder's Day Address by Mrs. George Lloyd
Mount Vernon College Alma Mater, Voice and Piano, Stanzas 1-4

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains audio tape reels. The tapes capture campus ceremonies, celebrations, and special events on the Foxhall Road campus. They range in date from 1950 to 1975, with the bulk of the tapes dating between 1968 and 1975. Of note is a recording of the 1970 dedication ceremony for the Florence Hollis Hand Chapel.

scopecontent.p: Speakers: Mr. Pelham, Mrs. Holland, student president

did.unittitle: "Mount Vernon Past and Present" Soundtrack for Alumnae Luncheon Slideshow

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: 3-inch reel, 7 1/2 ips, Mono, 2 tracks, Spliced, Side 2 blank.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From original box:
Creator and performer: J. Schubert.

Old piano music from silent film era accompanies old Mount Vernon College slides. "New" sound of Hollywood fanfare accompanies the "new look" of Mount Vernon College. Voiceover leads into the question, "Where do we go from here?" Show used as intro to President's pitch on current conditions at Mount Vernon College.
